skill.name: changelog-automation
skill.description: Automate changelog generation from commits, PRs, and releases following Keep a Changelog format. Use when setting up release workflows, generating release notes, or standardizing commit conventions.
skill.summary: Automate changelog generation and release workflows using industry standards
skill.author: wshobson

security_audit.summary: This skill contains documentation and configuration templates for changelog automation tools. All static findings are false positives: network URLs are documentation references to keepachangelog.com and semver.org, backtick patterns are code examples in markdown format, and env_access references are configuration samples for GitHub Actions workflows. No executable code or security risks detected.

content.user_title: Automate Changelog Generation and Release Workflows
content.value_statement: Managing changelogs manually is error-prone and time-consuming. This skill provides patterns and tools for automating changelog generation, release notes, and version management following industry standards like Keep a Changelog and Conventional Commits.
actual_capabilities: Generate changelog templates following Keep a Changelog format
Configure Conventional Commits validation with commitlint
Set up automated release workflows using standard-version or semantic-release
Create GitHub Actions workflows for automated versioning and releases
Configure git-cliff for fast Rust-based changelog generation
Implement Python commitizen for interactive commit creation
limitations: Provides configuration templates only, requires installation of actual tools
Does not execute commands or modify repositories directly
Configuration examples may need customization for specific project needs
GitHub Actions examples require appropriate repository permissions

use_cases.title: New Project Release Setup
use_cases.description: Set up automated changelog generation for a new Node.js project using standard-version, commitlint, and GitHub Actions for consistent release workflows.

use_cases.title: Migrating to Conventional Commits
use_cases.description: Migrate an existing project to Conventional Commits standard with validation, automated versioning, and changelog generation to improve release consistency.

use_cases.title: Multi-Language Release Automation
use_cases.description: Configure changelog automation for projects in different languages using appropriate tools like semantic-release for Node.js or commitizen for Python.

prompt_templates.title: Basic Changelog Setup
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me set up a CHANGELOG.md file following Keep a Changelog format for my project

prompt_templates.title: Configure Conventional Commits
prompt_templates.prompt: Configure commitlint and husky to enforce Conventional Commits in my Node.js project

prompt_templates.title: Automate Release Workflow
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a GitHub Actions workflow that automatically generates changelogs and creates releases using semantic-release

prompt_templates.title: Custom Release Configuration
prompt_templates.prompt: Configure standard-version with custom commit types and changelog sections specific to my project structure

output_examples.input: Show me a basic Keep a Changelog template
output_examples.output: A markdown template with sections for Unreleased, Added, Changed, Deprecated, Removed, Fixed, and Security, following the keepachangelog.com specification with proper semantic versioning links.

output_examples.input: What are the Conventional Commit types I should use?
output: feat: New features (triggers MINOR version bump)
fix: Bug fixes (triggers PATCH version bump)
refactor: Code restructuring (maps to Changed section)
perf: Performance improvements (maps to Changed section)

output_examples.input: Configure git-cliff for my Rust project
output_examples.output: A complete cliff.toml configuration file with conventional commits parsing, GitHub integration, and templated changelog sections formatted according to Keep a Changelog standards.

best_practices: Use commitlint with husky to validate commit messages before they are created, preventing invalid commits from entering the repository
Configure separate workflows for manual and automatic releases to support both scheduled releases and emergency hotfixes
Define clear commit type conventions in team documentation and configure parsers to match your specific workflow needs
anti_patterns: Do not manually edit generated CHANGELOG.md files as changes will be overwritten on next automated release
Avoid mixing multiple unrelated changes in a single commit, which makes automated categorization inaccurate
Do not skip commitlint validation during development as it leads to inconsistent changelogs and broken automation

faq.question: What is the difference between standard-version and semantic-release?
faq.answer: standard-version requires manual triggering and gives you control over when releases happen, while semantic-release fully automates releases based on commit messages in CI/CD. Use standard-version for manual release approval, semantic-release for complete automation.

faq.question: How do I handle breaking changes in my commits?
faq.answer: Add an exclamation mark after the type (feat!) or include BREAKING CHANGE: in the commit footer. This triggers a MAJOR version bump and highlights the change prominently in the changelog.

faq.question: Can I customize which commit types appear in the changelog?
faq.answer: Yes, all tools support customization. In standard-version use .versionrc.js, in semantic-release use commit-analyzer options, and in git-cliff use commit_parsers in cliff.toml. Set hidden: true or skip: true to exclude types.

faq.question: Which tool should I use for a Python project?
faq.answer: Use commitizen for Python projects. It integrates with pyproject.toml, supports interactive commits, and can update version files in Python packages automatically.

faq.question: How do I migrate an existing project to Conventional Commits?
faq.answer: Start by adding commitlint configuration and husky hooks, then use changelog_start_rev to begin tracking from a specific version. Previous commits can remain in old format while new commits follow the convention.

faq.question: What permissions do GitHub Actions need for automated releases?
faq.answer: The workflow needs contents: write permission to create releases and commits, and may need pull-requests: write for release PRs. Use GITHUB_TOKEN for basic operations and NPM_TOKEN only if publishing to npm registry.
